etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French goujon, from Latin gobio(n-), from gobius ‘goby’

definitions: a small edible European freshwater fish, often used as bait by anglers.
shortDefinitions: small edible European freshwater fish, often used as bait by anglers

definitions: a credulous or easily fooled person.

etymologies: Middle English: from Old French goujon, diminutive of gouge (see gouge)

definitions: a pivot or spindle on which a bell or other object swings or rotates.
shortDefinitions: pivot or spindle on which bell or other object swings or rotates

definitions: the tubular part of a hinge into which the pin fits to unite the joint.
shortDefinitions: tubular part of hinge into which pin fits to unite joint

definitions: a socket at the stern of a vessel, into which a rudder is fitted.
shortDefinitions: socket at stern of boat, into which rudder is fitted

definitions: a pin holding two blocks of stone together.
shortDefinitions: pin holding two blocks of stone together
